data.title: Short films also part of 10th annual Hell's Half Mile, see what's playing
data.meta_description: In addition to the 18 feature-length films the Hell's Half Mile Film & Music Festival is screening for its 10th year, a substantial number of short movies are also lighting up downtown Bay City screens.
data.text:
BAY CITY, MI -- In addition to the 18 feature-length films the Hell's Half Mile Film & Music Festival is screening for its 10th year, a substantial number of short movies are also lighting up downtown Bay City screens.

The short films are to be packaged in several programs and screen during the fest, which runs Thursday, Sept. 24, through Sunday, Sept. 27. The exact schedule of the fest is pending but is to be announced soon at hhmfest.com.

Here are descriptions of the shorts:

1. All Your Favorite Shows! (animation, 5 minutes)

Synopsis: An energetic short that follows a boy through his day and his attachment to his handheld device, this short cuts together animation with film and television clips. Anything you wanna watch in the palm of your hands! Crazy convenient. Crazy...

Writer and Director: Danny Madden

Recently Screened At: SXSW, PBS Online Film Festival, Maryland Film Festival

2. Aphasia (narrative, 12 minutes)

Synopsis: Those digital doodads that people are always pulling out of their pockets and fiddling with nowadays might just spell the end of conversation as we know it. If you don't know the meaning of aphasia, you will by the end of this provocative short.

Cast: Robin Rose Singer, Frankie J. Alvarez

Director: Luke Locurcio

Writer and Producer: Robin Rose Singer

Producer: Olivia Bosek

Recently Screened At: Tribeca Film Festival, Palm Springs International ShortFest

3. Ausstieg Rechts (narrative, 6 minutes)

Synopsis: It's a troubling scene: a racist blowhard bullies an innocent black man on a bus. Then he tries to bully other passengers into backing up his repugnant views. Fortunately not everyone on board is on board.

Cast: David Wurawa, Cornelius Obonya, Thomas Maurer

Writer and Director: Rupert Holler

Writer and Producer: Bernhard Wenger

Recently Screened At: Schweinfurter Kurzfilmtage (Germany), Elswhere Film Festival (China), Festival of Nations (Austria)

4. Clown Service (narrative, 14 minutes)

Synopsis: A clown for hire will brighten up any kid's birthday party, but could one brighten up the life of an adult who's feeling blue? Tig Nataro tests the value of personal clown therapy in this heartwarming comic vignette.

Cast: Tig Nataro, Nathan Barnatt, Stephanie Allynne

Writer and Director: Tig Notaro

Producer: Rosie Kaller

Recently Screened At: Nashville Film Festival, Crossroads Film Festival, Vulture Fest

5. Death Has A Son (narrative, 8 minutes)

Synopsis: Death gets more than he bargained for when a woman trades sex for her life. Now he's spending the day with the bastard son he never wanted. Things are looking grim.

Cast: Tom Siedle, Victoria Nugent

Writer & Director: Zack Ogle

Producer: Peter Davis

Recently Screened At: Love Your Shorts Film Festival, Brouhaha

6. Elder (documentary, 13 minutes)

Synopsis: If you're a Mormon sent out on your first mission there are worse places to go than coastal Italy. But if you meet a handsome young activist just as you're discovering your own sexuality things could get complicated. This film pairs Mormon Elder Tom Clark's unique oral history with a trove of archival 8 mm footage.

Cast: Tom Clark

Director: Genea Gaudet

Producer: Tyler Measom, Manjula Varghese

Recently Screened At: Tribeca Film Festival, Newport Beach Film Festival, Outfest Los Angeles

7. Fixed (narrative, 7 minutes)

Synopsis: Jemimah is five years old and desperate for her dog, Tilly, to have puppies. When she learns her parents plan to have Tilly desexed, Jemimah embarks on a quest to get Tilly pregnant.

Cast: Amara Harnisch, Paul Treasure, Alitia Harnisch

Directors: Codey Wilson, Burleigh Smith

Producers: Burleigh Smith, Rob Viney

Writers: Casey Binsali, Tarier Majak, Jack O'Keeffe, Nathan Smith, Codey Wilson, Burleigh Smith

Recently Screened At: Tropfest (Australia), Nashville Film Festival, Fargo Film Festival

8. Get Better Boss (narrative, 6 minutes)

Synopsis: A terminally-ill Hong Kong crime boss has always dreamed of being a Western movie hero. As a last sendoff, his underlings set out to indulge his dream no matter what it takes. A rollicking East-West hybrid set to scintillating synth-pop.

Cast: How Chung, Nathan Truong, Jay Kwon, Julia May Wong

Writer & Director: Henry Kaplan

Producers: Penelope Essoyan, Josh L. Gordon, Maegan Houang

Recently Screened At: Bare Bones International Film Festival, Nashville Film Festival

9. Oh Lucy! (foreign language narrative, 21 minutes)

Synopsis: Setsuko is a middle-aged "office lady" in Tokyo. When her fickle niece quits her English lessons, Setsuko agrees to step in to take her place. Little does she know that the lessons, taught by an oddly attractive American instructor, come with a blonde wig and a whole new identity.

Cast: Kaori Momoi, Miyoko Yamaguchi, Billy Scott

Writer, Director and Producer: Atsuko Hirayanagi

Producers: Michael Chua, Razmig Hovaghimian, Masumi Soga, Ken Natsuhara, Perry Loong, Kunio Takahashi

Recently Screened At: Cannes International Film Festival (World Premiere - Cinefondation Selection), Flickerfest (Best Short Film), Sundance Film Festival (Short Film Jury Award: International Fiction)

10. Pink Grapefruit (narrative, 11 minutes)

Synopsis: A young married couple invites two single friends out for a long weekend in Palm Springs. It does not go as planned.

Cast: Wendy McColm, Nathan Stewart-Jarrett, Matt Peters, and Nora Kirkpatrick

Writer and Director: Michael Mohan

Producers: Shana Eddy-Grouf, Adam Hendricks, John Lang, Greg Gilreath

Writer: Chris Levitus

Recently Screened At: Sundance Film Festival, SXSW, Bermuda International Film Festival

11. Self-Help (narrative, 10 minutes)

Synopsis: A lonely man has an odd nightly routine.

Cast: Charles Green

Writers and Directors: Rob Tiffin, Ben Lamm

Director: Mitchell Hardage

Recently Screened At: World premiere

12. Selling Rosario (narrative, 16 minutes)

Synopsis: There's a deal being set up for the services of Rosario, the 12-year-old daughter of migrant laborers. Shady characters make hushed phone calls and pass wads of cash in secret rendezvous. It all looks pretty grim, but looks aren't always what they seem.

Cast: Mia Xitlali, Robert Renderos, Cristina Valle, Alma Martinez, Julieta Ortiz

Writers and Directors: Iana Simeonov, Michael Winokur

Producers: Emily Miller, Rey Godoy

Recently Screened At: Napa Valley Film Festival, Rhode Island International Film Festival, Palm Springs International Film Festival

13. The Cat's Cradle (narrative, 16 minutes)

Synopsis: A night of intimacy for Jim and Amy, a young couple looking to conceive, turns into a night of confessions and mutual betrayal that changes their relationship forever.

Cast: Nabil Vinas, Tawny Sorensen

Director: David Spaltro

Producer: Craig Nobbs

Writer: Tawny Sorensen

Recently Screened At: Soho International Film Festival, Twin Cities Film Fest, Emerge Film Festival

14. The House is Innocent (documentary, 13 minutes)

Synopsis: If you were house hunting and happened upon the former home of a murderess who buried bodies in the yard, you'd probably expect the real estate agent to warn you about it. But some people go for precisely this sort of thing, like the homeowner couple in this darkly humorous short doc.

Cast: Tom Williams, Barbara Holmes

Director: Nicholas Coles

Producers: Alexis Manya Spraic, Max Velez

Recently Screened At: Tribeca Film Festival, Rhode Island International Film Festival, Sidewalk Film Festival

15. The Story of A Rainy Night (foreign language narrative, 24 minutes)

Synopsis: We follow a lonesome old man as he shuffles around his house on a rainy night. Suddenly the house fills with children, grandchildren, and in-laws. There are hugs and happy conversations, or so it seems. With its point-of-view cinematography, this haunting Iranian short limns its main character's receding grasp on reality.

Cast: Mehdi Fard Ghaderi, Arash Ghasemi, Aref Namvar

Writer and Director: Mehdi Fard Ghaderi

Producer: Iran's Youth Cinema Association

Recently Screened At: Riverside International Film Festival, Fear No Film Festival, Tehran Film Festival

16. The Unexpected (foreign language narrative, 5 minutes)

Synopsis: Antoine has a serious problem making important decisions. Life doesn't seem real for him. But reality is coming...

Cast: Hubert Benhamdine, Delphine Herrmann, Helene Seuzaret, Huguette Benhamdine

Writer, Director and Producer: Hubert Benhamdine

Director: Gregory Bendrihem

Recently Screened At: Cote Court en Val d'Oise

17. Warning Labels (narrative, 14 minutes)

Synopsis: You see them on everything: drugs, cleaning products, appliances, office supplies ("watch for paper cuts," etc.). This cute short follows two Centers for Disease Control Employees on their first date and asks: what if potential mates came with the same warnings as everything else?

Cast: Karen Gillan, Josh Lawson, Eric Christian Olsen, Rose McIver

Director: Jennifer Morrison

Producers: Andrew Carlberg, Andrew Kelly, Ashley Lent

Writer: Janelle Riley

Recently Screened At: Tribeca Film Festival

18. What's Eating Dad? (narrative, 10 minutes)

Synopsis: There's nothing more stressful than meeting your boyfriend's parents, especially if his Dad's a zombie and you're meeting for dinner. Hijinks ensue in this hilariously absurd horror-comedy about literally surviving the future in-laws.

Cast: Morgan Wright, Brennan Taylor, Barbara Miluski, Joel Haberli

Writer, Director and Producer: Michael Goldburg

Producer: Dave Chan

Recently Screened At: Red Hook International Film Festival, Houston Comedy Film Festival, Atlanta Horror Film Festival

19. Yvonne (narrative, 9 minutes)

Synopsis: Yvonne has stopped doing the cooking, dishes, and laundry. To make matters worse, she's abandoned her family and set up camp in the refrigerator. This sharp, surreal short imagines the consequences when Mom disappears into everyone's favorite domestic appliance.

Cast: Marissa Jaret Winokur, Adam Kulbersh, Victoria Kelemen

Director: Andrew Putschoegl

Producers: Andrew Putschoegl, Steven Rowley, Joe Russell

Writers: Sandy Frances Duncan (short story), Steven Rowley
